title: 2 Easy Ways to Connect a PlayStation 4 Controller to a Phone

steps.title: On your Android, open the Settings app.
steps.content: On your Android, open the Settings app. This is the cog icon. Make sure your Android device is updated . You'll need at least Android 10 or newer to connect a PS4 controller.

steps.title: Tap Bluetooth.
steps.content: Tap Bluetooth . You may need to click Connections to find this option. If Bluetooth isn't already enabled, tap the toggle so it turns blue.

steps.title: Tap Pair new device.
steps.content: Tap Pair new device . Your Android device may already be in pairing mode.

steps.title: On your controller, press and hold the PS and Share buttons.
steps.content: On your controller, press and hold the PS and Share buttons. Do this at the same time. The Share button will be Create on some controllers. The light bar will begin to flash, and the controller will be in pairing mode .

steps.title: On your Android, tap your controller name.
steps.content: On your Android, tap your controller name. If this is the first time you're pairing your controller, it will be listed underneath Available devices or similar.

steps.title: Tap OK.
steps.content: Tap OK . This will connect your controller. You can now use your controller with a supported app. To disconnect your controller, turn off Bluetooth.

steps.title: On your iPhone, open the Settings app.
steps.content: On your iPhone, open the Settings app. This is the grey cog icon. iPhone currently supports PlayStation DualShock 4 Wireless Controller. You can also connect a PlayStation 5 controller. [1] X Research source You'll need iOS 13 or newer to connect a PS4 controller. Make sure your controller is charged and completely turned off.

steps.title: Tap Bluetooth.
steps.content: Tap Bluetooth . This is near the top of the screen. If Bluetooth isn't already toggled on, tap it so the switch turns green.

steps.title: On your controller, press and hold the PS and Share buttons.
steps.content: On your controller, press and hold the PS and Share buttons. Do this at the same time. The Share button will be Create on some controllers. The light bar will begin to flash, and the controller will be in pairing mode.

steps.title: On your iPhone, tap your controller name.
steps.content: On your iPhone, tap your controller name. If this is the first time you're pairing your controller, it will be listed underneath Other Devices . The controller will connect, and the light bar may change colors. You should see Connected next to your controller name. If the controller is paired to your iPhone but not on, press the PS button. To disconnect your controller, turn off Bluetooth.

steps.title: Restart your iPhone or Android.
steps.content: Restart your iPhone or Android. A simple restart can fix software bugs, such as issues with your Bluetooth.

steps.title: Let the controller charge fully.
steps.content: Let the controller charge fully. If the controller won't connect, it may not have the necessary charge to hold its sync. It takes about 2 and a half hours to fully charge .

steps.title: Reset your controller.
steps.content: Reset your controller. Find the small button on the back of your controller. Use a small, pointed object like a paperclip to push the button for 5 seconds, and then release.

steps.title: Update your wireless controller firmware.
steps.content: Update your wireless controller firmware. You'll need a Windows PC and the Firmware updater app. Download the installation file from the PlayStation website and run the app. You'll need to connect your controller to your PC during this process.
